author: Maarten Mittner
title: Rand a runt again on risk aversion | Markets
text:
Picture: THINKSTOCK Related articles Rand’s recovery pauses in volatile session Rand firmer after rebound from record low EDITORIAL: Don’t waste gains from weak rand THE rand on Tuesday boomeranged from another new low in a day of volatility.
It weakened to R14.1595/$ in early morning trade, before firming to R13.95/$ at the close of the local markets.
The rand firmed alongside currencies in other emerging markets, with Russia’s rouble and the Turkish lira strengthening against the dollar.
Though risk aversion persisted, it was not as intense as Monday’s rout.
The rand outlook remained highly uncertain as global factors, including the US interest rate and the performance of the Chinese economy, continued to weigh on the exchange rate, FNB economist Alex Smith said.
The risk was that the rand could depreciate more in the short term.
"As the US still hasn’t lifted its interest rate, we do not know the extent to which a rate hike is priced into the rand/dollar exchange rate at present," Mr Smith said.
Against the euro, the rand was at R15.6831 from R15.8180 previously and was at R21.1573 against the pound from a previous close of R21.3375.
Analysts expect the rand trade to remain volatile as risk aversion dominates ahead of a possible US rate hike later this year.
Some reckon the rand would then recover, as most of the devaluation effect would have been priced in. However, there is also a possibility the currency would continue weakening.
"With global equity markets and commodities continuing on the path to destruction the rand will continue to be sold off," Standard Bank trader Warrick Butler said.
The rand has dropped about 15% to the dollar since the start of June and was on pace for its worst quarterly performance since 2011, according to Iress data.
Investec economist Annabel Bishop has partly blamed the South African Reserve Bank for the renewed weakness in the rand, saying it softened after hawkish comments at the September monetary policy committee meeting. The Bank signalled further interest rate increases.
Since the monetary policy committee statement on September 23, foreigners had sold R2bn worth of SA equities, Ms Bishop said.
Meanwhile, though some of the rout in global markets eased from Monday, equity markets touched a two-year low on Tuesday as the outlook for raw materials prices and emerging markets remained soft.
Platinum fell to $894, its lowest since December 2008, on fears that the emissions scandal embroiling German vehicle manufacturer Volkswagen could hit demand from the automotive sector.
Mining and trading company Glencore, whose shares fell by almost a third on Monday on investor concern over its debt levels, bounced up 16.7% in London but only after its Hong Kong-listed shares fell 29%.
Earlier, Asian shares slid to three-and-a-half-year lows on China slowdown concerns.
Copper steadied after hitting a one-month low. It last traded at $4,977.50 a tonne, up 0.3% on the day but within reach of a six-and-a-half-year low below $4,855.
With Reuters, Bloomberg
